title: 114_hr4783
content: The Act titled "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs to 2022, along with administrative funding. Required expenditure amounts are also specified. The "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends SBIR program funding percentages annually from 3.46% in 2018 to 4.50% in 2022 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to increase STTR program funding percentages annually from 0.50% in 2018 to 0.60% in 2022 and beyond. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Annual reporting requirements under the Small Business Act have been amended to specify deadlines for submitting reports to Congress and the Administrator, with the deadline for submission set for December 31 and March 30 of each year, respectively. The Small Business Administration has updated reporting requirements under the Small Business Act, setting deadlines for agencies to submit annual reports by March 30 of each year. The Small Business Administration has updated reporting requirements under the Small Business Act, setting deadlines for agencies to submit reports by specific dates each year. The Small Business Administration has updated reporting requirements under the Small Business Act, setting deadlines for agencies to submit reports by specific dates each year. The amendments include deadlines for annual reports and failure to report administrative funds by March 30 of each year. Federal agencies must submit a report to the Administrator detailing how authorized funds were used during the fiscal year. Failure to submit the report will result in the agency not being able to use the funds unless a report is submitted along with a plan for timely reporting in the future. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to redesignate subparagraphs, strike certain clauses, and add a new subsection. The Small Business Act is amended to include new subsections regarding awards under Phase I and Phase II of SBIR or STTR programs, with Phase I awards capped at $150,000 and Phase II awards capped at $1,000,000, adjusted for inflation. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act to change wording regarding insertion incentives. SEC. 7 clarifies eligibility for certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify eligibility for certain small businesses under the SBIR and STTR programs. The Administrator is required to modify policy directives to ensure that specific small business concerns are eligible to receive awards. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify eligibility for certain small businesses under the SBIR and STTR programs by modifying policy directives. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program, requiring covered agencies to implement a program to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires covered agencies to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The program must not exceed 5% of the agency's total SBIR budget, and it will terminate on September 30, 2022. Matching funds are required for awards under the program. Under a commercialization assistance pilot program, a matching amount equal to the award must be provided from an eligible third-party investor before the end of the program. Ineligible funding sources cannot be used for the matching requirement. Awards under this program cannot exceed certain limitations and will be distributed during the Phase II award period. Awards under the commercialization assistance pilot program are distributed during the Phase II award period. To receive a second sequential SBIR award, an eligible entity must submit an application with required information and matching funding details. The funds awarded can only be used for specific purposes. The commercialization assistance pilot program awards funds for research and development activities that accelerate commercialization. Recipients are determined based on the potential impact on commercializing research and the feasibility of the proposed plan. The evaluation criteria for the commercialization assistance pilot program include assessing technical feasibility, improvements to the Phase II plan, progress in Phase II activities, third-party funding expectations, and the potential for commercial and societal benefits. The evaluation report, due three years after the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016, will summarize the activities and results of the commercialization assistance pilot programs, including the number of small businesses that received awards. The evaluation report will summarize the commercialization assistance pilot programs, including the number of small businesses that received awards, the rate of commercialization success, growth in employment and revenue, comparison with non-matching Phase II recipients, demographic information of participant companies, funds usage at each agency, and distribution of third-party funding. The evaluation report for the commercialization assistance pilot programs will include an analysis of funds used at each participating agency, distribution of third-party funding, program effectiveness, and recommendations for improvement if made permanent. Definitions include 'covered agency' as a Federal agency with an SBIR program and 'eligible entity' as a small business with Phase II awards. The term 'eligible third-party investors' refers to small business concerns, venture capital firms, individual investors, non-SBIR government entities, or a combination of these, while 'ineligible sources' include the awardee's internal R&D funds and non-cash funding like in-kind or intangible assets. The term 'eligible third-party investors' includes small business concerns, venture capital firms, individual investors, non-SBIR government entities, or a combination of these. Ineligible sources of funding are internal R&D funds, non-cash funding like in-kind or intangible assets, funding from owners or affiliates, and funding obtained through loans or debt obligations. SEC. 9. INCREASED UNDERSERVED POPULATION PARTICIPATION WAIVER REMOVED. Federal agencies must allocate funds to increase participation in States with historically low SBIR awards. Conforming amendment removes waiver authority under certain conditions.
